I encounter this somewhat often (regularly enough to be an annoyance). I remember a non-sponsored site also not working another time due to in-between tracking URLs, but I don't recall which page so have no proof of it ever happening. > > In my opinion, if an ad (or sponsored search result, which I have enabled in my AdGuard settings) shows up it should also work. The g2a website itself is not blocked, it is just one or more tracking pages in between that are. Username: `@Hedge4` ### Screenshots

This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has been open for 4 days with no activity.
Unfortunately, our resources are limited and we can not always take the time to respond to requests about websites that are not popular enough. The issue will be closed if no further activity occurs.
Please note, that AdGuard Filters is an open-source project that is used by different content blockers and we welcome contributions. If you have some technical knowledge about how websites work, you are welcome to create a pull request following [these instructions](https://github.com/AdguardTeam/AdguardFilters/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).

issue.title: Getting rid of JS rules, used to set a cookie

labels.name: Infrastructure
labels.description: Related to the repository infrastructure

labels.name: A: In progress
labels.description: Work on the issue is in progress

issue.body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] I checked the documentation and found no answer;
- [X] I checked to make sure that this issue has not already been filed;
- [X] This is not an ad/bug report.

### Problem description

### Prerequisites

- [X] I checked the documentation and found no answer;
- [X] I checked to make sure that this issue has not already been filed;
- [X] This is not an ad/bug report.

### Problem description

We have ~317 JS rules, used to set a cookie. They can be found by:
`document.cookie =`
They must be replaced by `set-cookie` / `set-cookie-reload` / `trusted-set-cookie-reload` scriptlet rules.

There are many old rules, so first you need to check if the site is available, and then the need for the rule.

* For convenience, you can work in a separate browser
* Retrieve the list of domains, clean up duplicates and check if sites exist (if redirects occur, we assume that the site is dead).
* All such rules can be merged into one file, convert them to exception rules and import as custom filter. Then go down the list and check if the rules are needed (other types of problems not related to these rules are skipped).
* If the site is dead - add domains in the comment below. Then we will remove them from the filters.

In order not to overlap with other filter maintainers, it is desirable to perform batch rule replacement via pull-requests (5-10 rules per PR).

### Important
It should be checked with a Dutch or German VPN, because otherwise the cookie usage messages may not appear.

Not reproduced with AdGuard filters on my end.
Try to leave only AdGuard filters below without other extensions, clear browser data, update the filters (wait almost one minute there), open the site.
If that doesn't work, you should re-enable the content blockers in Safari settings (wait about the same time as when you update the filters).
```
AdGuard Base
AdGuard Tracking Protection
AdGuard Annoyances
AdGuard Chinese
```

comment.body:
Blocking Google Analytics... fine. But come on, our very own pixel that I have developed myself doesn't track anyone, it doesn't even use cookies. As explained in our privacy policy, we only collect aggregated metrics (daily number of page impressions per article, user-agent, etc). ComputerBase is a small independent publisher and we need some aggregated metrics to work with. This has nothing to do with "tracking".

(Furthermore, please consider that Firefox will become even more irrelevant for web developers if it becomes completely invisible in [charts like these](https://www.computerbase.de/2024-09/chrome-firefox-etc-welche-browser-nutzt-ihr-bei-computer-und-smartphone/). And I think we all agree that Firefox is important for a healthy web.)

When at some point in the future there is nothing left but paid subscriptions and AI-generated crap you might come to realize that what you participated in was sometimes a little over-the-top.
